attributes.comment:
Re: Proposed Adjustment of the Immigration and Naturalization Benefit
Application and Petition Fee Schedule, DHS Docket Number USCIS-2006-0044

To Whom It May Concern:

This letter is in opposition to the proposed fee increases for the I-600/600A orphan
petitions required of adoptive families.

Because of the instability concurrent with international adoption, many families
find that their USCIS approval expires prior to their invitation to travel to their
prospective child's birth country. As a result, many families find themselves
repeating the entire immigration application two or three times. If USCIS would
simply extend the "expiration" deadline for the I-171H from eighteen months to
three years, it would significantly reduce its workload without having to increase
its fees.

While we agree with the aims of the Department of Homeland Security, the
additional level of scrutiny on orphaned children and their prospective parents is
absurd.The idea that adoptive parents are a threat to national security is
laughable!

Many adoptive families have been through years of infertility and loss, and are
mortgaging homes and cleaning out life savings to bring home a child. Increasing
the burden is not simply unfair; it is detrimental to the lives of waiting children. Is
adoption only for the rich? In the words of our 5 year old adopted daughter, after
being home a year, ?...but everyone deserves a family?. We urge rejection of the
current proposal and a new requirement that USCIS reduce the fee burden on
adoptive families, give first priority to I-600/600A applications, consolidate the
paperwork required for orphan petitions, and extend the "expiration" of the I-171H
from eighteen months to three years.

Sincerely,
Brad and Kathleen Poindexter
Danville, Virginia

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
